-------Custom_Dialog_Box_One-------
If you need inspiration then try this link which will take you to one example of the many beautiful and inspiring videos of human achievement.
Click me!\n\n
If you can’t access sites like youtube then take a break and listen some music that inspires you and makes you feel good or look at a picture that makes you feel calm and in a good place’ whether it’s a mountain, a beach, your favourite car or a loved one (we are all different).\n\n Do Something to reset your mental state. Trust us.. It makes a big difference.
-------Custom_Dialog_Box_Two-------
"Often when we describe a problem we describe the symptoms instead of the underlying problem that it is causing the symptom/issue.
For example a symptom might be “my staff members performance is very poor but I cannot talk to them about it because they accuse me of bullying them”
Whilst the underlying problem could be “I have a really bad relationship with my staff member, there is a mutual distrust and it means everything is a fight” or “from what I can see, if a staff member accuses a manager of bullying, my company will always back the staff member and punish the manager” "You can click ‘Next’ now, but you may want to take this opportunity to double check you have noted down the specific underlying problem or issue, not just a symptom.
"You can click ‘Next’ now, but you may want to take this opportunity to double check you have noted down the specific underlying problem or issue, not just a symptom.
-------Custom_Dialog_Box_Three-------
It is ok if it is, we just need to double check this before we continue to make sure we help in the right way
10 Death\n\n
9 In danger of death\n\n
8 You are about to become homeless or experience a full mental/health breakdown\n\n
7 You may be about to lose your job or get a divorce if this issue is not resolve successfully\n\n
-------User_Dashboard-------
We provide Business Psychology Consultancy and Training services.
-------About_Us-------
"" Sometimes we just need someone to help us see what we already know - but are too busy or stressed to realise.""
This \'Quick Coaching\' App we will ask you some questions that will help you find perspective and solutions for tour problem, or help you plan to achieve your goal
-------Play_Back_Summary-------
Why do you want to overcome or resolve this issue?
What do you feel is at stake here?
Issue or problem is appropriate?
How could you influence or improve the situation? (If you chose to)\n Explain?
Improvements
How will going through this situation make you stronger and wiser?
What are the implications
What positives can take from this situation?
-------Ask_Your_Self-------
1.) What…specifically…is the challenge here?
2.) What can I do or put in place, to male this challenge easier?
3.) What would be the first step in doing that?
4.) Is there anyone who can help me?, Is there anyone I know who would find this much easier? if there is - what would they do differently?
5.) Can I do that? (the action that someone else would take) - if not, what would need to change so I could do that
6.) Am I missing any information here? If so what is it and where can I get it from?
-------Last_Question-------
(Make sure this is a precise timing point such as "Monday at 9:00am". Answers such as "as soon as possible" will not help you much. The more specific you can get the date and time the more likely you are to actually do this)
-------Display_Summary-------
Your goal is to:
Which you want to achieve because:
//how to overcome them and you plan to start your first action on:
We hope this simple coaching exercise has helped.\n\n If you are still unsure why not reach out the wider leadership community on this app. We have some great moderators and friendly experts ready to help.
-------RUN_TEXT-------
One of the simplest examples of a road map is planning for something like a marathon run. There are clear stages that lead up to this goal such as running 18miles, running a half marathon, running regularly, finding the time, Getting work and partner on board, doing the first run and maybe even buying shoes…
-------OVERCOMING_CHALLENGES-------
In any plan there may be challenges. That is ok.
The key here is to focus on how to overcome those challenges instead of \"these are reasons why I should not do this\".
On the next screen you will see your road map plan again with the
hazard icons next to the steps you indicated may be a challenge.
-------PROGRESS_CHECK-------
Ok so you have a clear goal, an understanding of why you want achieve it, a plan to achieve it and you have identified where the challenges may be.
Now let\'s sense check this and get you started.
-------WHY-------
It can help us understand\n our motivation to go deeper
For example: if you want a promotion and more money to afford a new house - keep asking yourself WHY do i want this?
-------WHY_GOALS_STATEMENTS_ARE_SO_IMPORTANT-------
Goal statement are important because: They identify the real goal or WHY They often show other ways of achieving the ultimate or deeper goal.
For example in the goal statement above we can see that perhaps “getting promoted” is not the best way to achieve the “more money”, which enables “a house”, which enables a “new life with my partner”.
Perhaps what we should really be focussing on here is changing to a more lucrative career, Moving to a different region or country, or focussing on our credit rating to enable a better mortgage offer.
-------BUILDING_A_ROADMAP_PLAN-------
Our next action is to build a set of steps that will help you achieve your goal. This is called a road map. Or more accurately a “reverse engineered road map”.
-------BUILDING_A_ROADMAP_PLAN_2-------
A good reverse engineered road map starts with your destination or goal. It then works backwards to identify each step that needs to take place in order to achieve the goal. It can also identify milestones and measurabes if you need it to. Next you will find two examples of road maps.
------CONFIDANT-------
It looks like you\'re not feeling that confident. That is OK.
Think about why you have given this the rating you have and ask yourself these questions:
1.) What…specifically…is the challenge here? - Why can\'t this be rated as an 9,8 or 10?\n\n 2.) What can you do or put in place to make this challenge easier?\n\n 3.) What would be the first step in doing that?\n\n 4.) is there anyone who can help you?\n\n
5.) Is there anyone you can think of who would find this much easier?\n\n
6.) What would the person you are thinking of do differently? Could you also do that?\n\n If not, is there anything you need to change so that you could do that?\n\n 7.) Are you missing any information? What else do you need to know?\n\n
If so, what is the information and where can you go to get it?
------RESPONDS-------
Thinking of the\n issue or problem,\n has you’re your\n response so far been\n appropriate?"
------ROADMAP_CEHCK_POINT-------
Click "NEXT" again to continue to the next stage or close this text box and add more steps to your road map
------ARE_U_SURE-------
Are you absolutely sure that there is nothing that you could do to influence or improve the situation? Very rarely is there truly nothing we can do. – There is an old saying that ‘the only things in life that are certain are death and taxes’. This saying implies that these are the only things we can not truly change. But health gurus and accountants will agree that although you cannot stop death or taxes, - you can certainly influence them! Think again about your situation and focus on what you can do to influence or improve them. If you are still struggling with the idea that you can do anything to affect the situation, watch this short video…
Recognising when you are stress is the first step managing it and building your resilience. Here are some common signs of stress, select all the ones that apply to you:
-- RESILIENCE ----
Visualising something that\n makes you happy - can\n actually make you happy.
When you think of a place,\nperson or activity that makes\nyou happy, level of stress chemicals\n such as dopamine and \noxytocin go up.
Find an image that makes\n you feel good now......
Any of these images working\n for you?\nIf not use photos on your\n phone, or Google Image search
------Resilience_Slide_16-------
We recommend that you contact\n at least one of the following\n people:
------Resilience_Slide_18-------
When you slow your breathing\n rate or pulse rate you can change\n stress levels.
Use a pluse monitor to measure\n heart rate.(Fibit etc.).Or, take\n your own pulse at your wrist, neck\n or chest. Countto yourself.
------Resilience.Slide_12_Behavioural-------
Recognising when you experience too much stress is the\n first step managing it and building your resilience.\n Here are some common signs of stress.\n Select all things below that apply to\n you:
------Resilience.Slide_19-------
Some people like imagine they\n are taking in energy (oxygen) as\nthey breath in, and letting go of\ntension and stress as they\nbreath out.
Remember by controlling your\nbreathing you are\ndirectly changing your\nbrain and calming your ‘stress\nresponse’. This is all part of\nresilience.
------Resilience.Slide_26-------
1 min exercise is better than\n no exercise. To release\n dopamine, you need to expend\n effort; get a little out of breath.\n you need to visit a gym or\n run a marathon.
It\'s not about time, it\'s about\n effort. A few press-ups or a\n short run can release\n dopamine (a reward\n chemical). See how you feel\n after doing just that initial 60\n seconds of fast activity, then\n stop, breathe deeply and\n consider if you want to do\n another 60 seconds…
------Resilience.Slide_28-------
Take a few minutes to list as many things as you can to be grateful for, once you have finished press Next:
Take a few minutes to list as many things that cheer you up or make you happy
------Resilience.Slide_30-------
Go to a park, forest or some\n countryside. Just a few minutes in a natural environment can\n make a difference to our\n emotional state (how we feel) and how we are perceiving\n things.
------Resilience.Slide_31-------
A common cause of stress and\n causes of burnout is trying to\n please everyone and not feeling\n able to say ‘No’.
Learning how to say ‘No’ in a\n collaborative, professional\n way that does not invite conflict,\n can make a huge difference to\n stress levels…
